title: 'The silence over the horrific death toll in Gaza speaks volumes about Israel's transformation'
summary: While it was predictable that the shockwave of October 7, 2023, would prevent any compassion for the Palestinians by Israel for a long time, another barrier also fell after those massacres: the one that once protected certain values that Israel claimed to uphold, writes Le Monde columnist Gilles Paris.

title: Netanyahu says Israel killed Mohammed Sinwar, Hamas's presumed leader in Gaza
summary: Israeli media outlets reported Sinwar was targeted in Israeli air strikes in southern Gaza earlier this month. His brother, the mastermind of the October 2023 attacks, was killed in October 2024.

title: War in Ukraine: Germany announces new financial and military cooperation with Kyiv
summary: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz announced that the two countries would jointly produce long-range missiles, enabling strikes deep inside Russia.

title: Brothers Andrew and Tristan Tate are charged with several counts of rape, assault and trafficking
summary: Social media influencer Andrew Tate faces 10 charges in the UK, including rape, relating to three women. His brother Tristan has been accused of 11 similar charges against one woman. Both men have denied all charges against them.

title: In Japan, newly released archives reveal the scale of human experimentation between 1938 and 1945
summary: Newly uncovered documents confirm Japan's ambition to develop biological weapons during the Pacific War. The infamous Unit 731 of the Imperial Army in Harbin, China, was not the only group to use human test subjects.

title: 200,000 barrels of radioactive waste at the bottom of the sea: Scientists set out to inspect a nuclear dump in the Atlantic
summary: Scientists from various disciplines are spending a month at sea to locate these barrels, which were submerged between 1950 and 1990, and to assess their impact on marine biodiversity.

title: Russia proposes new Ukraine talks, Kyiv demands terms upfront
summary: Ukraine said it had already submitted its peace terms to Russia and demanded Moscow do the same. The two sides held their first direct talks in over three years on May 16 in Istanbul, but that encounter failed to yield a breakthrough.

title: US vows to 'aggressively' oust Chinese students
summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, on Wednesday, said the United States will 'aggressively revoke visas for Chinese students, including those with connections to the Chinese Communist Party or studying in critical fields.' Young Chinese people have long been crucial to US universities, which rely on international students paying full tuition.

title: Alcaraz, Swiatek and Sabalenka reach French Open third round
summary: Four-time Grand Slam winner Carlos Alcaraz reached the third round of the French Open on Wednesday. Meanwhile, Iga Swiatek is bidding to become the first woman to win four consecutive French Open titles in 102 years, and Aryna Sabalenka − who has never reached the final − is hoping to banish the memories of a painful quarter-final loss to Mirra Andreeva in 2024.

title: A French court has jailed a former Syrian rebel for war crimes
summary: Majdi Nema − better known by his nom de guerre Islam Alloush − was found guilty by a Paris court and has been sentenced to 10 years. He was charged under the principle of universal jurisdiction, which allows states to prosecute suspects accused of serious crimes regardless of where they were committed.

title: Poland's presidential election: Trump administration openly backs nationalist candidate
summary: The organization of a CPAC conference in Poland on Tuesday was an opportunity for US Republicans to support the PiS candidate in the face of 'wokeism' and 'globalism.'

title: War in Ukraine: Zelensky proposes a trilateral 'Trump-Putin-me' meeting
summary: In a fresh call for truce talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky proposed meeting together with US President Donald Trump, after Putin rejected previous proposals.

title: 'Proud to be parliamentarians': How French MPs set aside divisions to back right to assisted dying
summary: A bill on assisted dying was passed 305-199 after respectful debates, far from the usual controversies or heckling characteristic of the divided house. The bill will now move on to the Sénat.

title: In Gaza, a father describes the struggle to feed his family
summary: Mahmud Al-Haw shares his arduous journey to feed his family. After a three-month blockade, Israel has allowed very few aid trucks to enter Gaza in recent days.

title: In Gaza, Israel's new food distribution system turns to chaos
summary: The new aid delivery mechanism designed by the United States and Israel to bypass Hamas has sidelined NGOs. Footage showed the disastrous results of the initial deliveries.

title: French Open first round illustrates France's decline in women's tennis
summary: Only three French women advanced to the second round of the French Open, matching the worst years on record. Varvara Gracheva, who lost, was the only Frenchwoman in the Top 100 going into the tournament.

title: Former surgeon Le Scouarnec handed 20-year sentence in France's worst child abuse case
summary: After a long trial, in which Joël Le Scouarnec admitted to 299 counts of rape or sexual assault, most of which were committed on children under 15, the court sentenced him to 20 years in prison, the maximum sentence.

title: UK government renationalizes first railway company
summary: On Sunday, the British company South Western Railway returned to public ownership. This marks the first step in a renationalization of the railways, ending nearly 30 years of private management.

title: Germany toughens rhetoric toward Israel, but maintains policy stance
summary: Long a staunch supporter of Israel due to its responsibility for the Holocaust, Berlin has begun issuing increasingly firm criticisms of the war in Gaza. However, it continues to deliver arms to Israel.

title: Elon Musk announces government role departure, thanks Trump and says DOGE mission 'will only strengthen over time'
summary: US administration officials were often vague about when Musk would step back from his position spearheading the Department of Government Efficiency, known as DOGE, and he abruptly revealed that he was leaving in a post Wednesday on X.

title: Thousands evacuate as Canada's Manitoba province declares wildfire emergency
summary: More than 17,000 people in Canada's western Manitoba province were being evacuated on Wednesday, as the region experienced a terrifying start to wildfire season. Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew declared: 'This is the largest evacuation Manitoba will have seen in most people's living memory.'

title: 'Menopause leads to an average 10% loss in income'
summary: After motherhood, menopause is the second leading factor that increases wage inequality between women and men, observes Pauline Grosjean in her column for Le Monde.

title: Trump administration cancels contract with Moderna to develop bird flu vaccine
summary: The $590 million contract, signed days before Trump took office, was scrapped by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr, who has spent decades promoting misinformation about immunization.

title: How was the European Union created?
summary: On July 23, 1952, the European Coal and Steel Community was established – the first supranational community in Europe. How did this first step toward European integration happen?

title: What do Christians celebrate on Ascension Day?
summary: On May 9, Christians celebrate the Ascension, symbolizing Jesus' ascent to God. Le Monde explores the history and symbolism of one of Christianity's most important feasts.

title: Swiss village destroyed by glacier collapse, one person missing
summary: The collapse had been expected for several days and the village of Blatten had been evacuated. A mix of falling ice, rock and mud destroyed it.

title: Macron decorates Indonesian leader with France's highest honor
summary: On a visit to Indonesia, French President Emmanuel Macron awarded his counterpart Prabowo Subianto with the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honor.

title: US federal court overturns Trump's 'liberation day' tariffs
summary: The decision, a victory for business circles that had failed to make the US president back down on the issue, disrupts ongoing trade talks and undermines the president's strategy of issuing and retracting threats. His administration immediately filed an appeal.

title: Maria Grazia Chiuri steps down as creative director of Dior women's collections
summary: LVMH announced the departure of the designer who led Dior's women's collections for nine years. Her lengthy tenure allowed her to develop her own language within a fashion house whose heritage she respected.

title: Victims of pedophile surgeon Le Scouarnec express anger and fear after trial's verdict: 'Our voices must go beyond the courtroom, or we will be forgotten'
summary: The criminal court sentenced Joël Le Scouarnec to the maximum penalty for the rapes and assaults of 299 people, most of them children at the time. But plaintiffs were upset the judges did not apply a measure that could have further lengthened his detention.
